instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P3V3S0_EN: What is P3V3S0_EN? This signal enables the PP3V3_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.S5_PWR_EN: What is S5_PWR_EN? S5_PWR_EN is a signal that turns on all S5 power rails when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P3V3S3_EN: What is P3V3S3_EN? P3V3S3_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_S3 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.DDRREG_EN: What is DDRREG_EN? DDRREG_EN is an enable signal that turns on power rails for DDR memory.
definitions.P1V8S3_EN: What is P1V8S3_EN? P1V8S3_EN is a signal that enables the PP1V8_S3 line when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P1V05S0_EN: What is P1V05S0_EN? P1V05S0_EN is a signal that enables the PP1V05_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
Hello,
I'm trying to fix a motherboard who doesn't turn on from an 2015 macbook pro 13"" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A.
No trace of corrosion at all.
When I plug the charger, the magsafe light start from orange for half a sec then turn green then turn to Orange.
I did SMC Bypass: the light on the magsafe start orange and turn green when I release the power button. It turn back orange when I press again power.
Nothing on the screen, no fan spinning.
I'm using an 60w apple official charger.

I took some measurement :

[B]<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]12.55V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]4.99V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]3.42V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> [/B]- [B]0.08V[/B]

I've been looking for [B]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_XXX</SIGNAL> [/B]:

[B]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]3.33V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]Pulse few ms once when the charger is plugged in then go to 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]Pulse few ms once when the charger is plugged in then go to 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]Pulse few ms once when the charger is plugged in then go to 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]3.33V[/B]

[URL='https://www.it-tech.com.au/mac-q-a/pm-slp-s4-l-timing/']I look on internet[/URL] and see that I need 11+1 prerequisites to turn on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> to enable S4, S3 and S0 state power rails.

1. [B]<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]3.33v[/B]
2. [B]<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]3.26v[/B]
3. [B]<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]3.26v[/B]
4. [B]<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>[/B](?_L?) : [B]2.51v[/B]
5. [B]<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>[/B](?_L?) : [B]2.51v[/B]
6. [B]<SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL>  [/B]- Can't measure it because I don't have oscilloscope
7. [B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]3.33v[/B]
8. [B]<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]3.42v[/B]
9. [B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]3.33V[/B]
10. [B]<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]3.30v[/B]
11. [B]<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]3.03v[/B]
+1. [B]<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]3.41V and stable[/B]

From what I understand from [URL='https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-no-<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.61141/']this post[/URL], <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> is coming directly from the PCH so it's :
- the PCH who is bad
- connection from the PCH to the PCB who is bad
- "series resistances"
Is that correct and if yes, which "series resistances" is it ?

Additional measurement :
[B]<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]1.67v [/B](seem bad too)

Best regards

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"From what I understand from [URL='https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-no-<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.61141/']this post[/URL], <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> is coming directly from the PCH so it's"
Wrong understood; that is a PCH input.

"<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> : 1.67v"
Is the only bad reading; it is also PCH input.
And PCH will not start power on sequence untill get the correct level.
Force it with 100K instead of 1M in place of <RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
Hello 2informaticos and thanks for the answer :).
Thanks for the correction.
I put a 100k resistor instead of the 1M in place as <RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR> and have now <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> at 3.29V.
Unfortunately, still no sign of life.

Assuming this : [URL]https://logi.wiki/index.php/G3_to_S3_State_for_Ivy_Bridge_Haswell_and_Broadwell[/URL]
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> : 3.03v being a good value, I understand that I can have a clock issue

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
When I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drop at 0.32V and come back to 3.42 after release.
Sometime, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> Stay at 0.32V until I cut the power.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
Other information :
When plug in the charger in
[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> [/B]pulse at [B]0.6V [/B]then go to 0V
[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> [/B]pulse at [B]0.7V[/B](sometime 2.41V) then go to 0.07V
[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> [/B]pulse at [B]0.7V [/B]then go to 0.07V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
You should note the pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals at same time with drop pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
Be sure <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> is always/steady high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
Values when charger is plugged :
[B]<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> [/B]is at [B]3.03V [/B]and is stable
[B]<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> [/B]:  [B]3.42v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> [/B]is at [B]0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> [/B]is at [B]0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> [/B]is at [B]0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> [/B]is at [B]3.34v[/B]

When I trigger [B]<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> [/B]:
[B]<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> [/B]is at [B]3.03V and is stable
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> [/B]pulse to [B]1.5v [/B]then go back to 0v
[B]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> [/B]pulse to [B]1.41v [/B]then go back to 0v
[B]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> [/B]pulse to [B]1.31v [/B]then go back to 0v
[B]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> [/B]is at [B]3.34v and is stable
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> [/B]drop at [B]0.32V [/B]and go back to [B]3.42v[/B]

I Just realized that using my multimeter to check pulse could be not enough fast to catch accurate pulse value in this scenario. Unfortunately I don't have other measurement tools at my disposition ...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
If you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> repedeatlly, may catch higher value.
However, 1.5V pulse can't be catched if respective signal doesn't pulse; good enough as confirmation.
You should check for pulse now on each power rail according with <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> used as enable.

Try first to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
I tried to start in <SIGNAL>SMC_BYPASS</SIGNAL> mode, but my fan will not speed at all (should turn at full speed from what I understood) and 0V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL>.

These are the highest values I caught by trigger [B]<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> [/B]repedeatlly :
[B]<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>[/B] pulse at [B]2v
<SIGNAL>DDRREG_EN</SIGNAL>[/B] : pulse at [B]2.37v
PM_SLP_S4_BTMUX_[/B]L : pulse at [B]2.43v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL>[/B] : pulse at [B]1.41v
<SIGNAL>P1V05S0_EN</SIGNAL>[/B] : pulse at [B]1.53v
<SIGNAL>P1V8S3_EN</SIGNAL>[/B] : pulse at [B]2.34v 
<SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL>[/B] : pulse at [B]1.52v 
<SIGNAL>P3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL>[/B] : pulse at [B]2.34v 
<SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>[/B] : pulse at [B]2.31v 
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN_RC</SIGNAL>[/B] : pulse at [B]1.08v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>[/B] : pulse at [B]0.7v 
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>[/B] : pulse at [B]1.04v 
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL>[/B] : pulse at [B]0.6v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL>[/B] : pulse at [B]1.35v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> [/B]: pulse at [B]2.3v [/B]then go to [B]0.07v  stable[/B].
[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> [/B]: pulse at [B]2.01v [/B]then go to [B]0.07v stable[/B].
[B]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> [/B]:  pulse at [B]3.72v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> [/B]: pulse at [B]5v
<SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> [/B]: pulse at [B]2.35v
<SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> [/B]: [B]3.42V stable
<SIGNAL>USB_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> [/B]: pulse at [B]1.23v[/B]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
Check for pulse at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.
Be sure no corrosion present on its area.

Any pulse at L7630 and L7310/20?

You can also test the board removing <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
[B]<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>[/B] [B]:[/B]
no visible corrosion
[B]Pin 7[/B] : pulse at[B] 2.40v
Pin 3[/B] : pulse at [B]1.10v

L7630 :
Pin 1[/B] (<SIGNAL>P1V05S0_LL</SIGNAL>) : pulse at [B]1.2v
Pin 2[/B]  (<SIGNAL>PP1V05S0_REG_R</SIGNAL>) : no pulse

[B]L7310 :
Pin 1[/B] : no pulse
[B]Pin 2[/B] no pulse

[B]L7320 :
Pin 1[/B] : no pulse
[B]Pin 2[/B] no pulse

I removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> but I can't notice any change on the measurement

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
As per schematic, L7310/20 are tied together (on output pin); no need to measure both of them.
Also keep in mind, DC voltage must be checked on output pin; no reason to check both pins of a coil.

Really strange to get pulse on pin 3/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> but not on L7310/20 (VCORE).
Use quality flux and heat PCH die area.
No more than 200 degrees, for 15-20s; no need to melt the balls, just burn eventually accumulated crap.
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> issue denotes a problem on that area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
Thanks for the tips.
Unfortunately, I didn't change anything :(.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
Tie together pins 5/6 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and test again the board.
Also check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

Can you note pulse on all output voltages from page 63?
Check them for short to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
I made mistake and my ground probe touched some part of the motherboard and burnt something.
I don't know what exactly burnt, but the short came from that location just like the smell. 
Couldn't find anything burnt with my eyes.
[ATTACH alt="mb.jpg"]60598[/ATTACH]

The logic board is doing pulse by itself every 4 sec.
I can hear a little tick coming from [B]<TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR>[/B], [B]Y1915[/B], [B]Y1905[/B], [B]Y5110[/B]
I have no more drop pulse on [B]<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> [/B]when I trigger [B]<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> [/B]doesn't make any measurements I took before pulse anymore but still affect the led of the magsafe when maintain close when the charger is plugged, the led doesn't change of color.

[B]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: 0.07V and pulse at[B] [/B]2.3v ([U]was at 3.33v stable before[/U]) 
[B]<SIGNAL>PCH_PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL>[/B] : 3.33v stable
[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> :[/B] 0.07v pulse at[B] [/B]2.3v 
[B]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: 3.33V
[B]<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> [/B]: 3.33v

[B]ppvrtc [/B]:[B] [/B]3.33 stable
[B]<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> [/B]:[B] [/B]3.26 stable
[B]<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> [/B]:[B] [/B]3.26v stable
[B]<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> [/B]:[B] [/B]2.51v stable
[B]<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> [/B]:[B] [/B]2.51v
[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> [/B]:[B] [/B]3.33v
[B]<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> [/B]:[B] [/B]3.42v
[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> [/B]:[B] [/B]3.33v
[B]<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: 3.30v
[B]<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: 3.03v
[B]<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: 3.41v and stable
[B]<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> [/B]: 3.0v

[B]<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> [/B]: 0v pulse at 1.50v

[B]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL>[/B], from what I understand, it's coming from [B]<CHIP>U1420</CHIP>[/B].
[B]<SIGNAL>PCH_PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> [/B]go to pin 1-2 of [B]<CHIP>U1420</CHIP>[/B].
[B]<CHIP>U1420</CHIP> [/B]is powered by [B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_PCH_GPIO</SIGNAL>[/B]
and should output [B]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL>[/B]

<SIGNAL>O_O</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Doesn't turn on - Magsafe Orange
threads.message:
I don't understand anything from that picture.
I can't see any location marked there.

Don't bother with <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL>.
In fact, I don't understand how did you get 3V there (first post), if this signal is pulled up to <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>.
As per schematic, <CHIP>U1420</CHIP> avoid high level on this signal, if machine isn't in S0 state.
